definitions.definition: that you would like to have or do; worth having or doing
definitions.sensetop: It is desirable that… It is desirable (for somebody) (to do something)

examples.text: She chatted for a few minutes about the qualities she considered desirable in a secretary.
Such measures are desirable, if not essential.
The house has many desirable features.
Experience of computers is highly desirable.
It is desirable that interest rates should be reduced.
It is desirable that interest rates be reduced.
It is no longer desirable for such young children to take formal written tests.
examples.contextForm: It is desirable (for somebody) (to do something)

examples.text: A new direction was felt desirable for both parties.
It is clearly desirable that domestic and European law should be compatible.
It is clearly desirable to have a common set of principles throughout the industry.
This kind of work is seen as desirable.
An end to the hostilities remains a highly desirable objective.

definitions.definition: causing other people to feel sexual desire

examples.text: She suddenly saw herself as a desirable young woman.

wordOrigin: late Middle English: from Old French, suggested by Latin desiderabilis, from desiderare ‘to desire’, perhaps from de- ‘down’ + sidus, sider- ‘star’.
